content.text: 8. What is the difference between a permanent contract and a fixed-term contract?

runs.text: What is the difference between a permanent contract and a fixed-term contract?

content.text: A permanent contract has no end date and continues until it is lawfully terminated. A fixed-term contract ends on the date or after the period that was agreed upon.

content.text: 16. What steps do employment disputes go through before reaching the courts?

runs.text: What steps do employment disputes go through before reaching the courts?

content.text: Employment disputes start at the Commission for Mediation and Arbitration (CMA). If no resolution is reached, the case may be taken to the Labour Court or the High Court, depending on the type of dispute.

content.text: 17. What should I do if I am dismissed without a written contract?

runs.text: . What should I do if I am dismissed without a written contract?

content.text: Having a written contract is not the only way to prove employment. The law also recognizes oral or implied contracts. If you are unfairly dismissed, you have the right to file a claim at the Commission for Mediation and Arbitration (CMA) within 30 days. Evidence such as pay slips, attendancy, emails, text messages, or witness testimony can be used to prove the existence of the employment.

content.text: 18. Does the absence of a written contract mean I have no rights as an employee?

runs.text: Does the absence of a written contract mean I have no rights as an employee?

content.text: No. Employee rights do not depend solely on having a written contract. Once you start working under the employer’s direction and receive payment, you have a legally recognized employment relationship and are entitled to all rights provided under the Employment and Labour Relations Act.

content.text: 19. What penalties can an employer face for failing to provide an employment contract to an employee?

runs.text: What penalties can an employer face for failing to provide an employment contract to an employee?

content.text: According to labour law, an employer who fails to provide a written employment contract is in violation of the law. They may be ordered by the Commission or Court to compensate the employee, pay a financial penalty, or issue a proper contract in accordance with guidelines from the Labour Department.

content.text: 20. Can an employer claim I have no rights because “we didn’t sign anything”?

runs.text: Can an employer claim I have no rights because “we didn’t sign anything”?

content.text: No. Although a written contract is emphasized, the law recognizes an employment relationship even without a written contract. If you worked for the employer, received a salary, and followed their instructions, that is enough proof of employment. You are still protected by the law and have the right to claim your entitlements.
